byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and SARAH MASLIN NIR
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Robert Davey, Kristin Hussey and Elizabeth Maker in Connecticut; Jess Bidgood in Massachusetts; Hattie Bernstein in New Hampshire; Richard Pérez-Peña and Nate Schweber in New Jersey; Matt Flegenheimer, Thomas Kaplan and Elizabeth A. Harris in New York; and Jen McCaffery in Rhode Island.

abstract: Surprise snowstorm leaves more than three million customers in the Northeast without power and compels governors in Connecticut, New Jersey, Massachusetts and New York to declare states of emergency; heavy snowfall closes down streets, schools and, in some cases, even Halloween celebrations.
snippet: By the time the great snowstorm of October 2011 finally ended early Sunday, more than three million customers would find themselves without power.
lead_paragraph: By the time the great snowstorm of October 2011 finally ended early Sunday, more than three million customers would find themselves without power.

headline.main: Cleaning Up After Nature Plays a Trick
headline.print_headline: Cleaning Up After Nature Plays a Trick
headline.seo: October Snowstorm Wreaks Havoc on Northeastern States
